climbs.name: CB Cool Down (Beyond the Permafrost)
climbs.fa: Matt MacPhee and James Kesten, July 2020

content.description:
P1 5.10a 25m: First moves off the ground are cryptic but solid once you find them. Might be able to stick clip the first bolt (recommended if you can make it happen). Make a few 5.10ish moves between the 2nd and 4th bolts, moving up on larger-than-expected holds for Nova Scotian granite. No real crux. Extend the second bolt with a runner. Holds get smaller as the route goes up, then finally make a few run-out feeling moves up to a set of rings in a belay alcove.

P2 5.10a 30m: You get a committing crux move immediately after clipping the first bolt. After that, it's smooth sailing up varied features. You might want to extend a couple of bolts around the huge stacked flake feature. Belay off of rings. 


This route starts in a bit of a broken right-facing corner, after you hike the trail over the often wet mini-gully, past the large block feature. 

Rack of 12 draws will get you to the top with plenty to spare. Can rap back to the ground in two rappels with a 60m rope.

climbs.name: Champions Club
climbs.fa: Matt MacPhee and Todd Foster August 2020

content.description:
P1 5.10d 25m: Warm up through three bolts on a gently overhanging flake with good holds, then use violence, speed and momentum to dominate the cryptic crux sequence. Take a quick rest when you clear the overhang before you tackle the vertical flake right under your nose. Be careful to not get lured too far left of the bolts through this two-time crux - you'll be rewarded with a home run jug to clip off of if you stay on route. Top out to rings on a party ledge. 

Firm handshakes to James, Kelly, Greg, and Curtis for helping with beta and not sending the route before me. 

P2 5.10b 30m: You thought you were at the tippy top of the mountain, but you're really only halfway up. Work your way through a series of bulges, flakes, dishes, corners and a variety of other features. There are two distinct cruxes but the rest is fairly sustained as well. The top rewards you with a comfortable belay ledge and a set of rings, along with a fantastic view of the arena. -

Here are some early reviews for Champions Club:

'One of the most unique climbs I've ever done. A real technical and mental test piece for the grade.' - G.H.

'Even while seconding pitch two on top rope, I almost soiled myself with vomit. I'll never climb this pitch again.The first pitch was cool, though.' - T. F. 

*This route was first climbed with just 11 bolts. Since the fa more bolts have been added to improve protection.



This route starts right in front of the Observatory, which is the aptly-named ledge feature that juts out into the valley. Look for three bolts trending left up a large flake feature before going straight up through the overhanging section. 

You can rap from the top in two raps with a 60m rope. 


A mixture of 15 sport and alpine quickdraws. Rap the route.

climbs.name: Highland Heatwave
climbs.fa: Todd Foster and Kelly Buchanan, June 2020

content.description:
The route starts down the gully past the beautiful birch tree. Follow bolts up the ramp and pull some fun moves around the two bulges. It would be helpful to extend the two bolts before the bulge to reduce rope drag later. About 35 meters to the first belay ledge. Pitch two, 20 meters up exposed but easier climbing to a second set of rings. An optional third pitch goes up then right across a ledge system. Continue angling up and right and then straight up for a nice long pitch of easy but very featured climbing. 35 meters

Pitch 1: 14 bolts, 5.9 35 meters

Pitch 2: 7 bolts, 5.7 20 meters

Pitch 3: 9 bolts, 5.7 35 meters

Pitch 3 finishes on a steep tree'd ledge. You can finish here and scramble up to the top of the wave wall and walk off like that, or rappel back down the rap anchors if you want to climb some of the other routes. 



Lots of bolts and bolted rappel stations. The route can be rappelled with a 60 meter rope but if you go to the top keep in mind that the third rappel will be a rope stretcher. Tie knots!

climbs.name: The Price Of Admission
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Emily Keast, Sept. 2020

content.description:
This is a fun multi pitch adventure on good rock with interesting features on every pitch. The climbing is never too hard but still quite thought provoking. Other than pitch 3 this is a sport climb! Only quickdraws needed for pitches 1,2 and 4. A very light rack of cams up to #1 BD are needed for pitch 3. 

Pitch 1 - Climb up large holds and big features to a tricky crux. Pull onto a sloping ledge where you will find a two bolt anchor and belay. 18 meters 6 bolts 5.10a

Pitch 2 - Step right off the anchor and head up on more good rock. Follow the weakness as it winds left and right several times before reaching a big ledge and bolted belay. 25 meters, 9 bolts, 5.8

Pitch 3 - If you brought a light rack of trad gear you can do this pitch. If you didn't you should rappel back to the ground. Step right across the ledge and aim for a low angle slab with several cracks. Move up the slab then start making an airy, exposed, horizontal traverse, clipping one bolt through a run out section. More gear will be found after the bolt as you continue moving right. Step down and aim for a narrow foot ledge that leads to a bolted belay. Make a few spicy moves across the foot ledge before clipping the anchor. 20 meters, 1 bolt, 5.6

Pitch 4 - This is the money pitch. Follow the incredibly featured, steep and intriguing dike as it flows up to a ledge. Move up and right off the ledge climbing a large flake that will take you to the top of the pitch and another bolted belay. 22 meters, 9 bolts, 5.8.

Gear: For pitch 1, 2 and 4 a mix of 10 draws of varying lengths will suffice. For pitch 3 a light trad rack of cams from small to a 1 inch piece. 6 cams would be plenty. 60 meter rope would be fine. Rap the route. If you do pitch 3 and 4 you will need to walk about 40 meters along the base to get back to your packs. 



This route is roughly in the middle of wall. To find the start take the approach trail that leads to the base of the wall. Head down a gully with a fixed rope. About 30 meters below the fixed line you will see an obvious dike with dark rock and blocky features. This is the start of the first pitch. 


Mostly bolts, small rack for pitch 3. Bolted belays. Rap the route.
This section is the entirety of the large ridge line that runs into the valley and is visible from the top of the main wall.
